abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Urban Poverty Project will
            improve services to the urban poor, by supporting community
            organizations that are able to increase the voice of the
            poor in public decision making, and, making local
            governments more responsive to the needs of the poor through
            increased cooperation with community organizations, through
            the provision of funds to community based organizations, and
            local governments for the provision of services to the urban
            poor. As a highly decentralized, and community-based demand
            driven project, it will support a large number of small
            subproject investments, mainly in urban areas, while the
            participatory nature of this project, should guarantee that
            people affected by project implementation will be involved
            in the decision making process. The design of the project
            therefore ensures the participation, and inclusion of all
            groups, including indigenous peoples and ethnic minorities,
            and, recognizes that isolated vulnerable people form a group
            that merits specific support. This Indigenous Peoples Plan
            (IPP) ensures that such groups do benefit from the project,
            and seeks to avoid, or minimize as possible, adverse effects
            on isolated and vulnerable people. Facilitator training
            shall provide the tools and mechanisms on how to organize,
            and work with vulnerable groups, including the ability to
            communicate in the appropriate language. It is expected a
            full participation, and awareness of their rights and
            responsibilities, in order to voice their needs. Monitoring
            criteria and grievance mechanisms will be established, to
            ensure compliance with this framework, and responsiveness
            should conflict occur, respectively.
